1782.post_content: WINNER 2014 Zepp Tour was a debut concert in commemoration of their Japan Debut Album 2014 S/S Japan Collection which sold more than 60,000 copies. The Tour had 11 Dates which started from Sept. 11 - Oct. 11, 2014 and gathered more than 25,000 fans.
1782.subtitle: Japan

1644.post_content:
2015 marks not only the comeback of BIGBANG after 3 years but the start of their "MADE" tour. Being 3 years since their first world tour and 2012 Alive tour, this tour will not only provide the platform to perform their new music but allow fans to experience and upgraded stage far superior than the past.

The tour kicks off in Seoul with back to back shows at the Seoul Olympic Park Gymnastics Hall on the 25th and 26th of April before embarking on a 15 country, 70 show world tour in front of an estimated 1.4 million fans. Aiming to reach total audience figures higher than most of todays top global stars, the world has garnered much interest in Korean group BIGBANG.

The “MADE” WORLD TOUR’s over the top concert video contents are bound to be an eye-catcher. The trailer video alone was produced at the quality of a blockbuster film. All locations were filmed in the United States, with a top-class local production crew of around 100 people. Ed Burke, long-time videographer and performance director for Beyonce, worked as the creative and visual director, while Dkeil Lemash, who led clothing photography shooting for Ralph Lauren and RRL, worked as the photography director. In addition, Jonathan Lea, who has produced music videos of Kanye West, Beyonce, Madonna, and other top stars, took part in the trailer as the producer and Nino Pansini of the Fast & Furious serious shot the car chase scene, arousing all the more interest from fans.

It doesn’t stop there. Lighting and production designer, Roy Bennett, who received “Designer of the Year Award” and is known for his work with acts in the 80s and 90s like the Scorpions and Prince, as well as global stars like Paul McCartney, Beyonce, Lady Gaga, and Rihanna, has been chosen as creative director for the concert stage.

After 4 years with the band, Gil Smith II has once again joined the tour as the music director to create an array of new arrangements that are bound to provide fans around the world with the best live music experience.

Ahead of the start of the world tour, there has been reservation wars worldwide, creating tension among fans eager to get a chance to see the show.
1644.subtitle: America & Oceania

1488.post_content:
ABOUT SHOWTIME TOUR

After the successful DEBUT CONCERT [SHOWTIME] in 2015, iKON is finally coming back with their very first Asia Tour in 2016.

The upcoming iKONCERT 2016 [SHOWTIME] TOUR will gratify the audiences with a more polished stage manner and creative performance, including new songs that were not performed at the last concert.

Through this tour in 2016, iKON, the hottest rookie of 2015, will highlight their first album [WELCOME BACK] with their energetic and passionate performances.

959.post_content:
Beyoncé is not God. She tells you as much about a third of the way through her Formation World Tour — which lit up Citi Field in Queens for the second of two nights on Wednesday — with two stadium-length illuminated screens bearing the words “God is God. I am not” in all caps. As it does during the snarling “Don’t Hurt Yourself” in her visual masterpiece Lemonade, the message flashes fast. Blink and you’ll miss it. The position is reinforced by moments that are, if only briefly, unmistakably human — such as when, on the first night of her NYC dates. Twice, politely and discreetly, into her arm, like any non-godly person, one not performing for a sold-out crowd at a stadium that last year co-hosted the World Series, might do.

But for many, witnessing Beyoncé let out a sneeze only adds to the mystique of feeling “close” to someone so seemingly godlike, prompting her otherwise quiet achoo to dominate the news cycle for an entire day. On her second night at Citi Field, Beyoncé’s bedazzled nude bodysuit ripped near the crotch during her finale — “Halo,” appropriately — moments after she and her apostolic all-female dancers create the illusion of walking barefoot on water. Beyoncé may not be God, but she still conveys an air of being more than human.


The Beyoncé that rises from the bitterness — and all the events that may or may not have inspired it — is a woman knocked off her axis. She’s been tortured, flung off a roof, gone rogue with a baseball bat, baptized in the holy water of redemption, and eventually resurrected. Every emotional flaw she exposes finds itself under her own microscope. Yet that vulnerability is absent from the Beyoncé brigade that marches out from behind the fog at Citi Field to open the show with the song from which the tour gets its name.
959.subtitle: [Dummy Data] Subtitle Placehold
